newsitem.title: HUNGARY: FORECAST - Hungary govt security yields seen steady.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Hungary govt security yields seen steady.

text.p: Hungarian government security yields on the secondary market were seen remaining steady this week or changing only slightly, traders said.
"Secondary market prices did not move much last week and I expect the same for this week," said Zsolt Bango of Gog Securities.
"The market over-reacted a little to recent inflation figures," said Tamas Puskas of Raiffeisen Securities.
The Central Statistical Office announced two weeks ago that September year-on-year inflation was 21 percent, down from 22.2 percent in September.
Dealers said last week's one- and three-month discount Treasury bill auctions have not given the market stimuli.
But a larger-than-expected drop in the yield of three-year government bonds at Thursday's auction was followed by a fall of 50 to 70 basis points in three-year yields to 21.5-21.6 percent, they said.
Discount Treasury bill yields dropped 10 to 20 basis points to 22.1-22.2 percent by Monday afternoon, they added.
Traders saw little room for further falls in the near future, with inflation forecast at 18 percent for 1997, and a market where liquidity was likely to tighten in December.
Dealers said yields on government security with longer maturities fell more sharply recently than on short-term papers, indicating the market view that inflation would fall further.

"Yields could drop to 21 percent by January only if the government's economic policies are convincing," said Creditanstalt's Gabor Szogi, adding that in the near future he did not see substantial drops in yields.
Puskas said that government bond yields could be even corrected slightly upwards on the secondary market this week.
